definition: to do more than is required (idiom); superfluous/gilding the lily
many/much/often/a lot of/numerous/more/in excess/how (to what extent)/multi-/Taiwan pr. [duo2] when it means "how"
this/these
one/1/single/a (article)/as soon as/entire/whole/all/throughout/"one" radical in Chinese characters (Kangxi radical 1)/also pr. [yao1] for greater clarity when spelling out numbers digit by digit
to lift/to hold up/to cite/to enumerate/to act/to raise/to choose/to elect/act/move/deed

sentences.english: But concerns over intellectual property rights have proved to be unfounded.
sentences.chinese: 對於知識產權問題存在顧慮顯然多此一舉。

sentences.english: To talk about the beautiful sunset is to gild the lily.
sentences.chinese: 談論日落之美是多此一舉。

sentences.english: Comment on this would be to gild the lily.
sentences.chinese: 這一評論就是多此一舉。

sentences.english: These regulations become largely redundant in an era of carbon taxes.
sentences.chinese: 這些規定在碳稅時代，很大程度上是多此一舉的。
運煤到紐卡索，多此一舉。

definition: variant of 小題大做|小题大做[xiao3 ti2 da4 zuo4]
to force someone to do something
complete nonsense (idiom)
to procrastinate/to stall for time/to filibuster
to speak without thinking (idiom)/to blurt sth out
to be a real headache/to find sth a real headache/to beat one's brains
to change one's mind/to go back on one's word
to flatter/to fawn on/to butter sb up/toadying/bootlicking
to take one's seat according to the ticket number/(fig.) to put (things or people) in their right place/to take a general comment as a personal attack
lit. chasing the wind and clutching at shadows (idiom); fig. groundless accusations/to act on hearsay evidence
double standard
to avoid the important and dwell on the trivial/to keep silent about major charges while admitting minor ones
Heaven knows!
to argue strenuously or with sophistry/to quibble
to ask for trouble/to invite difficulties
to spend effort/to take trouble/May I trouble you to...? (as part of polite request)/Please would you mind...?
